abstract.p: Richard Silkes letter, commenting on July 21 editorial, says Israelis and Palestinians must put aside their time-worn arguments for their right to Jerusalem and proclaim it a world city of peace to be safeguarded by international community

block.p: Re ''Overtime at Camp David'' (editorial, July 21): If a settlement in the Middle East is to be reached, Palestinian and Israeli peacemakers can no longer refer to the results of biblical title searches to lay claim on the future. Instead, they must look hard at the present, at the pivotal role they play in determining the events that will shape their children's lives.

Re ''Overtime at Camp David'' (editorial, July 21): If a settlement in the Middle East is to be reached, Palestinian and Israeli peacemakers can no longer refer to the results of biblical title searches to lay claim on the future. Instead, they must look hard at the present, at the pivotal role they play in determining the events that will shape their children's lives.

For both sides to win, both sides must be willing to lose their timeworn arguments for possession. Jerusalem is a spiritual focal point for the faithful of three great religions. No one people can claim it as its own without generating fear and suspicion. Both sides must stand together and proclaim Jerusalem as a world city of peace, to be safeguarded by the international community.
